choices.D: Apply network blacklisting rules for the adversary domain.
choices.C: Emulate the malware in a heavily monitored DMZ segment.
choices.A: Physically move the PC to a separate Internet point of presence.

questions.question_text: During an incident, a company's CIRT determines it is necessary to observe the continued network-based transactions between a callback domain and the malware running on an enterprise PC. Which of the following techniques would be BEST to enable this activity while reducing the risk of lateral spread and the risk that the adversary would notice any changes?

discussion.content:
B. could do it, and would be the best option so they can study the malware.
'Micro-segmentation is a network security technique that enables security architects to logically divide the data center into distinct security segments down to the individual workload level, and then define security controls and deliver services for each unique segment.'
A. could be a temp solution until the segmentation is done (if there are two answers).
tf two choices?

Selected Answer: C
wtf, 2 ans?
C."Emulate the malware in a heavily monitored DMZ segment" it provides an isolated environment for the malware to run.

Selected Answer: B
per the comments from others

Yes b
Organizations that adopt microsegmentation realize tangible benefits in the form of a reduced attack surface, improved breach containment, stronger compliance posture and streamlined policy management.
According to other sites, the answer is B

discussion.content: key word " lateral spread "
The question didn't say choose two. Also, why do we need to physically move the affected system

Separation of duties is the means by which no one person has sole control over the lifespan of a transaction. Ideally, no one person should be able to initiate, record, authorize and reconcile a transaction.

questions.question_text: An organization has a policy in place that states the person who approves firewall controls/changes cannot be the one implementing the changes. Which of the following is this an example of?

discussion.content: D is Correct An advanced persistent threat (APT) is a sophisticated, sustained cyberattack in which an intruder establishes an undetected presence in a network in order to steal sensitive data over a prolonged period of time.
First comment

questions.question_text: An organization just experienced a major cyberattack incident. The attack was well coordinated, sophisticated, and highly skilled. Which of the following targeted the organization?

HOTSPOT -
The security administration has installed a new firewall which implements an implicit DENY policy by default.

INSTRUCTIONS -
Click on the firewall and configure it to allow ONLY the following communication:
✑ The Accounting workstation can ONLY access the web server on the public network over the default HTTPS port. The accounting workstation should not access other networks.
✑ The HR workstation should be restricted to communicate with the Financial server ONLY, over the default SCP port.
✑ The Admin workstation should ONLY be able to access the server on the secure network over the default TFTP port.
The firewall will process the rules in a top-down manner in order as a first match. The port number must be typed in and only one port number can be entered per rule. Type ANY for all ports.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.
//IMG//

Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: This one was on my exam 06-15-2021

comments.content: TFTP is a simple protocol for transferring files, implemented on top of the UDP/IP protocols using well-known port number 69.

discussion.content: Answer looks mostly right to me except I would select UDP instead of ANY for the last 2 rules, as TFTP only uses UDP even if TCP port 69 is assigned to it.

" The HR workstation should be restricted to communicate with the Financial server ONLY, over the default SCP port." It says HR is restricted to Financial server but on the policy item 2 it shows hr ip allows to connect financial server via scp. Any thoughts?
Yes TFTP should be 69

questions.question_text: An organization has decided to host its web application and database in the cloud. Which of the following BEST describes the security concerns for this decision?

choices.A: Access to the organization's servers could be exposed to other cloud-provider clients.
choices.C: Outsourcing the code development adds risk to the cloud provider.
choices.B: The cloud vendor is a new attack vector within the supply chain.
choices.D: Vendor support will cease when the hosting platforms reach EOL.

discussion.content: Clear as mud! All except D could be the correct answer.

The correct answer would be B. The security concerns for hosting a web application and database in the cloud include the risk of the cloud vendor becoming a new attack vector within the supply chain. By using a cloud vendor, the organization is effectively outsourcing a part of its infrastructure, which means that it is relying on the vendor's security controls and policies. The organization must ensure that the cloud vendor has implemented adequate security measures to protect its systems and data. Other security concerns for cloud-hosted web applications and databases include data privacy, compliance, data backup, and disaster recovery.
B. The cloud vendor is a new attack vector within the supply chain.
The answer is B, I just took an exam with this question and it was right.

Yes the best answer is A
 because some cloud service provider do not give two factor authentication and this leads data breach

Still not sure about the answer.
Comptia is so rubbish with writing questions.

Wish someone can effectively explain this answer :/

Or at least point to which study tool can explain this concept better
An organization decided to host in the cloud. What drove them to such a decision. One answer.

If you chose A or B, you definitely have no clue about how the cloud works.
C. Outsourcing code development is a more legitimate concern, as they may not have the same levels of control as with the in-house/on-prem dev cycles.
